Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings based on inconsistencies in travel details and military exemption claims
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence, translation records
Legal_Provision: Section 96-97, IRPA (basis for refugee protection); Section 101(1)(a), IRPA (factors in determining refugee status)
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to Kurdish ethnicity and political activities
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection hearing, followed by judicial review
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Evidence_Ignored: Alleged poor translation quality, but deemed insufficient to affect outcome
Legal_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of bias, procedural fairness, standard of proof for refugee claims
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Decision_Review_Issue: Whether credibility findings were reasonable and process was fair
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility; correctness for procedural fairness
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: IRPA sections 96, 97, 101; principles of procedural fairness
Outcome_of_Review: Dismissed – no error found in Board’s decision
Evidentiary_Issues: Translation quality concerns raised but not substantiated
Procedural_Fairness: Assessed and found to be maintained despite translation concerns
Credibility_Issues: Inconsistent accounts of travel history and military service exemption
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Unreasonable credibility assessment and breach of procedural fairness
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms (implied procedural rights)
Omission_Type: Failure to provide consistent personal history details
